story: Gov to get , people new jobs by June - find outyou fit the criteriaThe UK Government’s Way to Work plan is getting job-ready candidates into new roles – and supporting employers in finding the right staffWork Coaches at Jobcentre Plus are already helping thousands of employers connect with the people they needAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Mar Looking to find a new job or fill a vacancy  Through Way to Work, Jobcentre Plus is offering employers a recruitment service that can quickly provide candidates who are the perfect fit.Jobcentre Plus has everything you need to move quickly. Right now, there are . million jobs available in sectors such as warehousing, logistics and manufacturing – so there are plenty of opportunities out there.For employers, Jobcentre Plus has thousands of quality candidates, ready to fill your vacancies quickly. The pandemic has been tough on everyone and highly skilled people have found themselves unemployed for the first time.Many may be considering a career change. These people can make a real dference to your business. And the UK Government is working with employers to get , job-ready candidates into work by the end of June. Many well-known companies already trust Jobcentre Plus with their recruitment needs – and you can too. To find out more, visit gov.uk waytowork. Eligibility criteria apply.aposWe had loads of jobs but not enough people to fill themapos  Screenprinting business Paul Bristow Associates is just one of the employers who’ve worked with Jobcentre Plus to fill vacancies. The family-run firm, based in Wrexham, produces textiles including T-shirts and printed bags – and they’ve been keen to attract younger people to roles. “One of the issues we have is the perception of manufacturing as being something we used to do in the Victorian age but no longer,” says director Ben Bristow. “Of course that’s not the case – but it made it hard to attract young people. Working with Jobcentre Plus gave us the ability to get more young people into the business and provide them with a good grounding in print and textiles.  “Our staff collaborated really well with the team at Jobcentre Plus, who gave excellent support and deserve high praise indeed.” HR manager Lee Dixon, , agrees: “The people who work there have done a fantastic job. It’s not been easy through Covid and the fact they’ve managed to help people into work is great. “It’s also massively helpful to us as an employer, given there are loads of jobs but not enough people to fill them. Through working with the team at Jobcentre Plus we’ve built up a great rapport. They’ve been first-class. “Our recruits have been a massive help in bringing in valuable skills to our business,” says Lee. “We’ve had them working in packing, admin, sewing and sales. Another guy has got a position in sustainability after he joined us from university. We’ve also had people with additional learning needs and disabilities.”aposMy team made me feel very welcome and supported meapos  “When I left college in January  I didn’t finish my A levels because I wanted a change, but then obviously the pandemic happened. I didn’t particularly know what I wanted to do, but I knew I would be good in a computer-based job because it’s something that I’ve gravitated towards. “Then I saw JD Sports was advertising opportunities and I thought I’d go for it because it was an administration role in a big company. It was actually the first that I applied for and everything went through really quickly – and I got the job. “My team at JD were great from day one. They made me feel very welcome and supported me. Day to day I’d look after anything from HR queries and issuing contracts to payroll and pension questions. It gave me pretty much a whole picture of what it’s like to work in HR and I’ve been doing it ever since. “I’d always had an interest in HR, but after working for six months I realised it was what I wanted to do. “There was the option to stay on and I’m now doing an apprenticeship with JD and CIPD Level  in HR support. It was another perfect step for me and I’ve now been there for a year and I’m really enjoying it. Starting work was quite tough, but I’ve got so much support from my team. It’s a lot more friendly than I expected it to be.“Now I’m learning about dferent parts of HR, building on what I was doing before. I was struggling to find any job with noexperience, but now I’ll just keep going.” Peter Cowgill, executive chairman of JD Sports, on how the company has forged links with Jobcentre Plus. “We are proud to have worked with Jobcentre Plus to provide much-needed employment and learning and development opportunities at a time when competition for job positions has been at an all-time high. Social inequality has only been exacerbated during the pandemic, so it has never been more vital to give young people a chance to succeed. “Our relationship with the DWP now covers all three nations across the UK and gives our stores, head office and distribution centres access to new talent pipelines and initiatives, which not only facilitates our future recruitment needs, but also allows us to support candidates facing social barriers, an area we are hugely passionate about.” “When I was developing my start-up in the renewable energy sector, working with Jobcentre Plus allowed me to recruit new graduates. “We’re part of the Edinburgh Business School incubator, where we get office space, mentoring and support. Since the graduates joined, we’ve moved to the stage of building a prototype.“If it wasn’t for the scheme, recruitment would have been years away –and having a few more minds to work on the concept has given us a competitive edge.“The candidates knew when they joined that they wouldn’t just be working on their own tasks and would be learning something every single day. If you’re looking for experience, it’s a great way to get it.” aposIt’s important to personalise our serviceapos  “Our service helps employers and our customers meet each other face to face, which is crucial. Employer advisers speak to both employers and the Work Coaches, who’ll send customers over who are ready for work. “We can also help employers st through CVs and hold training events to get people work-ready and match them up with the role they’ve got available. “I’ve been working closely with Lee at Paul Bristow Associates, who came along to events at the jobcentre where groups of young people could come and speak to him about what roles they had available. “A lot of employers weren’t aware of all the great services we offer, but the feedback we’ve been getting has all been really positive. Every employer’s needs are slightly dferent, so personalising our service is really important. “There are lots of sectors that are struggling to fill places, so we can help companies find a pool of candidates. We have large manufacturing areas in North Wales that are struggling to recruit people. There are also plenty of roles in the hospitality and care sectors.”Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Department for Work and PensionsJD SportsLee DixonJobs CentreMost ReadRecommended

story: Le in UK town where families have to beg for clothes and huddle in one room for warmthIn one of the UKs poorest towns those on the breadline have to make drastic choices to survive as the cost of living crisis hits, and say Rishi Sunaks Spring Statement does not go far enough.Across Greater Manchester, , people were on Universal Credit in February – .% of people aged  and over across the area Image: Manchester Evening NewsByPaige Oldfield:,  Mar |comments People living in one of the most deprived parts of the UK have to beg for clothes and huddle in one room for warmth as the cost of living crisis hits.Families are teetering on the edge and are regularly having to choose between starving and freezing as energy costs and food bills soar. They say Rishi Sunakaposs Spring Statement, with its p cut on fuel duty and National Insurance threshold increase, does not go far enough and the reality on the ground is stark.For people living in Oldham, Greater Manchester, where the number claiming Universal Credit has almost doubled in two years, day-to-day le is a struggle, reports the MEN. A trip to the town centre found a carer regularly surviving on one jacket potato a day, a pensioner whose food shop have soared from £ to £ and a mum who feels like a failure as she struggles to pay for school trips.Brits now face the biggest fall in income on record as inflation looks set to hit as much as %. In Oldham, a town with the second worst level of child poverty in the country, Julie Nuttall sits down clutching a polystyrene box. “This is our daily food,” she says, pointing down at her jacket potato. We might have a sandwich later, but this is our main meal.”It’s a hot March morning and the smell of baked potatoes fills the air. For Julie and her nephew Shaun, this food truck is a leline. It means they can afford to eat a proper meal today.“We’ve been walking aroundOldhamtrying to get the cheapest food we can,” the -year-old says. “We’re having child portions.”Like thousands of other families across Greater Manchester, Julie is facing the greatest uphill battle as the cost of living crisis cripples the country. A full-time carer for her disabled nephew, it’s a worry that keeps her up at night.“We do a lot of camping, we use an outside BBQ,” Julie, who lives in Hollins, said . “We’re going to have to make food on the BBQ just to cut back.“We’ve been given our bill for the next  months which has trebled in size. Weaposve switched the heating off now sowe get cold, we layer up. I know we have to pay and move on. But we have to cut back on usage and cut showers down. We have a disabled shower room which is going to make it dficult.  Weaposve had to cut back and prices are going back so we have to compensate somehow. Do you eat or heat  Thataposs the scenario. This time last year we were free. We could go into the community and come round here and not have to worry about what we had to eat. You go to bed and worry about what it will be like tomorrow. Barbara Szwandt stands outside a cafe with her daughter Janet. When asked about the cost of living crisis, a concerned look falls across her face.  The -year-old receives a pension but the money goes on rent and bills. Her financial situation once became so bleak, she was forced to beg people for warm clothes. Iaposve been struggling to get a coat and clothes,” she says. “Iaposve been going round askingpeople have clothes to spare. I donapost like begging and sometimes itaposs hard to do that. Her total food shop used to come to around £. Now, she claims it costs around £. Itaposs hard when you get £ a fortnight on pension, then you have to pay rent,” she continues. It doesnapost go nowhere. Thereaposs nowhere for anyone to speak to anyone and see what help is available. Iaposve lost contact with younger age groups I have to rely on my daughter to do things for me. I canapost do a proper shop. “What I used to get cost me about £, now itaposs costing £. Itaposs basically just bread, milk and potatoes.”  Mum-of-four Janet Szwandt gently rocks her three-year-old in his pram. The -year-old cares for four children, including her autistic son TG. Money is so tight at the moment she can’t afford to pay for school trips – something that makes her feel like a “bad mum”. Itaposs horrible you feel like an emotional train wreck,” she says. “You get up and you donapost knowyouaposre going to have enough to survive the next week. Weaposve had to cut back on every day stuff like going to play centres. You canapost do anything because everything has gone up.  “Weaposve had to cut back on the monthly shop because we canapost afford to do it and it costs us a fortune. You have to budget what you need to spend to survive. Itaposs gone from £ a month to £. My daughter wants to go on school trips and I canapost afford to pay it. We canapost get the bus, we have to walk. Itaposs so silly we have to live like this. Itaposs even affecting the kids because they canapost understand why they canapost have essential things. They canapost have them because itaposs so dear. They canapost have pocket money. It just makes you feel bad as a mum because you canapost afford to give them what they want. You canapost make them happy. With UK inflation soaring to .% - its fastest rise in  years - millions of households will be worrying about their own finances. The  cost of living crisis is hitting energy prices, fuel and the cost of food, with the governmentaposs only solution so far to offer all households a £ loan to help pay off their energy bills - which must be paid back eventually. Chancellor Rishi Sunakaposs Spring Statement saw him announce a cut in fuel duty, although this will cost the Treasury billions without putting cash back in familiesapos pockets. After paying his bills, he says he’s “lucky”he has £ leftover.Itaposs hard, itaposs very hard,” the -year-old says. “Iaposm having to rob Peter to pay Paul. Iaposm having to borrow money off friends. “Iaposm struggling Iaposm in financial dficulty I cannot afford and Iaposm a vulnerable adult. Iaposm having to cut back like on the essentials. Iaposm diabetic and insulin dependent. I canapost afford the food I need. I have to borrow off my friend. Itaposs really hard. The number has increased from , in February . The government donapost give a damn about us. Itaposs not fair. Iaposm not happy Iaposm content. But I would rather be happy, Terrance continued. story: Lotto pals who thought theyd won £, sat in silence as they realised it was £MILLIONNorthampton duo Marion Wood, , and Michael Williams, , both scooped £, after their syndicated National Lottery ticket matched five numbers and a bonus ballNorthampton friends Marion Wood and Michael Williams were left speechless after winning £,, Image: Sam Bagnall SWNSBySean McPolin:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA pair of hopeful Lotto punters who thought theyaposd won £, sat in stunned silence as they realised their prize was in fact a whopping £MILLION. Syndicate PALS Marion Wood, , and Michael Williams, , from Northampton, were left speechless after matching five main numbers and a bonus ball on the National Lottery earlier this month.As NHS worker Marion read out the pairs numbers, Michael was in the kitchen checking the digits and even gave out a squeak when he realised how many theyaposd matched.Marion works at Northampton General Hospital and Michael is a retired construction worker - both will take home £, each.  Speaking about the le-changing draw, which left both in stunned silence and needing a cup of tea, Marion said: “I was on annual leave, it was the Tuesday after the Saturday draw which we won on. Michael and I always check our tickets for the last draw just before the next one. He was on his computer in the kitchen, I was in the lounge. “I started to shout out the numbers on my ticket and he shouted yes, then yes, then another yes and then his voice changed - in fact he squeaked! There was another yes and the final yes was followed by a ‘Can you come here please ’”  When Marion wandered into the kitchen and looked at the numbers on Michaelaposs screen she originally thought the amount theyaposd won was £,. She added: “I looked, looked again, Michael was going through the numbers one by one, and he kept on saying it’s a million, it’s a milli - and I said ‘I don’t know what a million in numbers looks like !’ Due to it being late on a Tuesday evening the pair had to excitedly wait until the following day to ring The National Lottery and make their claim.  “I’m a big tea drinker, so we had a cup of tea and sat in stunned silence as we absorbed what had just happened, Marion said. I didn’t tell a soul at first, I just carried on as normal holding onto the lucky ticket wherever I went. I kept the ticket in my diary, which I keep in my purse, until the lady from Camelot visited to check it and confirmed that Michael and I actually were big winners. “Even now it still hasn’t completely sunk in, but seeing our names on the big cheque has definitely made it feel more real.” Asked how they will celebrate she said, “I’m still unsure about what sort of celebration we’ll have but I am getting a taste for champagne having sipped a bit since the win. “Working through Covid in the NHS has been tough. The amount of work has increased and, unfortunately, I have lost many family and friends. However, work has kept me going, I love my job and I won’t be leaving even after this amazing win.”  When quizzed on what the pair will spend their winnings on Marion admitted she wants to carry on as normal for a bit, adding: I’m from an army family and routine is important to me so I think I’ll just let my head get around it first. I might treat myself to some jewellery, it will be nice to have something special to remember how I felt when I won.” While Michael, a father of three who retired last year, revealed heaposs going to spend his money on a his first car since  and some rugby memorabilia. He added: Finally, I’ll also treat my family, they’ve been good to me and it will be lovely to do something nice for them.” Marion, originally from Caerphilly, Wales, bought the winning ticket on Saturday, March  from her local Morrisons using number of friends and family memberaposs birthdays. story: Mums nightmare hotel stay as she finds blood stains and bed bugs in roomKatie Moss claims she and her partner were met with blood on the door and wall, filthy carpets, a broken shower and s Coronation Street style bedKatie Moss and her partner were on their first break awayByGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar  A mum has told how she had a nightmare hotel stay after allegedly finding blood stains and bed bugsduring a romantic trip away.Katie Moss had hoped for a quiet break away from her kids with her partner. But the devastated couple claim they were disgusted by the stomach-churning condition of the room. Norbreck Castle Hotel describes itself as a stunning Castle like hotel offering a warm welcome to the famous Seaside Resort. Reviews on TripAdvisor give it a three-star rating, with some comments describing it as poor on the ratingsapos site.Katie Moss claimed to BirminghamLive she was met with blood on the door and wall, filthy carpets, a broken shower and s Coronation Street style bed during her stay. She claims it was a far cry from the aposmarble furnitureapos advertised online.And instead of having Christmas dinner at the hotel, she and her partner spent December  eating pot noodles on a perishing beach.She said: We got up to the room and I was like aposoh my Godapos. There was all blood up the door and up the wall. She added: It was not like the photos on Booking with the marble furniture, my bed was like something from Coronation Street in the s, wooden legs on little black wheels. The state of the room, she claimed, was so bad she didnapost feel she could even take her shoes off during the stay. She said: The carpet was full of this white chunky powder stuff and all over the cabinets and when I touched it with my hairbrush it crumbled offIt was wipeable so obviously it hadnapost been cleaned. There was hot chocolate all over the stairwell down the wall in the hallway. That was there when we got there and still there when I was checking out so that proved it wasnapost cleaned. Katie said they refused to eat at the hotel during their £ two-night stay and tried to spend as much time away from the venue as possible. She claimed she felt the need to buy her own cups after seeing the aposstateapos of the mugs provided. They had planned to go out of the hotel on Christmas Eve to enjoy a show they booked, but that was cancelled due to Covid. She said: I had to take sleeping tablets because all I did was cry. Christmas morning I was going to have my dinner there, thank God I didnapost. But instead I had to sit in the freezing cold on the beach with no where open Christmas day, starving.The couple instead had pot noodles for their Christmas dinner, finished off with digestive biscuits from a aposlittle hutapos on the beach and some hot donuts. The pair then checked out first thing on Boxing Day to head back on the pm coach to Birmingham. Katie said: I came back with bed bug bites, who gets bites in December  There were six in a little cluster on my left hip, where your bottom of your back starts. I can assure you I didnapost go with them. They appeared on the coach on the way back. She continued: I just wanted to try going away without the kids for the first time, my youngest is  now. I thought, aposno cooking, no stressapos. Wow it was the worst mistake of my le. Itaposs traumatised me I donapost think Iaposll go away again. I know you get those fussy guests but this was bad. It just ruined the whole Christmas. It was just horrendous. The way theyaposve tried to resolve the matter was even worse. Mrs Moss said she had complained to the hotel and was offered a  per cent refund. And though she had hoped for a full refund, months later, the £ still had not been issued. story: Mum who left concert soaked in own blood forced to wait  years for diagnosisMum-of-four Linda Hardaker, , from West Derby, says doctors dismissed her concerns as heavy periods, but she was finally diagnosed with endometriosis after a decade-long waitMum-of-four Linda Hardaker had a full hysterectomy after suffering for years with pains and heavy periods Image: Liverpool ECHOBySean McPolin:,  Mar |commentsA woman who left a concert soaked in blood because of her heavy periods was denied a diagnosis for more than  years. Linda Hardaker, , knew she was suffering with the same condition her mum, aunt and cousins had been for years when she first went to the doctor about her mood swings and painful periods, aged just . But the mum-of-fouraposs concerns were constantly dismissed as a heavy periods, even when at  she was leaving a concert with her pants literally saturated with blood.The florist, from West Derby, finally received a diagnosis for endometriosis at , after being rushed to Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital. She had collapsed and was in unbearable pain from a stabbing, twisting pain in her abdomen, the Liverpool Echo reports. Speaking about the problems around getting a diagnosis, Linda said: You start to doubt yourself. You start to think, aposIs this all in my head  Have I just got a really low pain threshold  Is this normal  Are these normal periods  Is this normal period pain  Am I just exaggerating  Am I just a wimp apos And obviously that affects your mental health. On average it takes seven years from the start of symptoms for people to be diagnosed with endometriosis. The incurable condition - which affection one in  women - sees tissue similar to the lining of the womb growing where in the body, as far away as someoneaposs lungs. It can cause debilitating pains during periods, when the lining sheds and the blood has nowhere to go like it would in the womb. Linda explained how the pains went away while she was on the contraceptive pill and during pregnancy, but came back with a vengeance.She added how she received le-changing treatment from Manou Kaur, a consultant at the Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital, which gave her her le back. Manou gave Linda a full hysterectomy, removing her womb and cervix - using a robotic assisted surgery.  I felt amazing after my surgery, Linda said. Compared to my c-sections, where I was awake and felt groggy, this was so dferent. Following my recovery, I went swimming for the first time and found that I could stretch my body and elongate my torso. Everything felt so stuck together before. Iaposm still finding new things I wasnapost able to do before the surgery. I feel so lucky. Itaposs made such a dference to the family. The Derby mum also diagnosed with premenstrual dysphoric disorder , which had left her anxious and unable to cope at times. Linda explained she was dumbfounded that it took until she was  for this to be diagnosed. She said: My struggles with my mental health and PMDD symptoms completely coincided with my cycle, and now itaposs lted.I wish I recognised it sooner and went on medication, because I feel like I missed out on opportunities with being either riddled with anxietyor feeling sad.At points, I turned up to the doctors sobbing and received depression medication. Nobody told me it could coincide with my cycle. title: pride britain winners camp boy
story: Pride of Britain winners camp with boy who spent  years sleeping in a tent for charityMax Woosey hosted his event Big Camp Out which saw more than  people come together to enjoy lovely food, a campfire singalong and a night under the starsSupporter Carol Vorderman visited on Saturday night with Max Image: RACHAEL WOOSEY APEXByClaire Donnelly:,  Mar |commentsIt was a night to remember for some Pride of Britain winners, when they joined host Carol Vorderman for a special camping trip. More than  people came together to enjoy great food, a campfire sing-song and a night under the stars at Max Woosey’s Big Camp Out. The -year-old has spent the past two years sleeping in a tent to raise more than £, for the North Devon Hospice. His mum Rachael, , said the event had been a huge success. “I slept out too, and we’ve all come away with a new respect for what Max is doing,” she said. “We were all cold and tired but he has been doing this every night for all this time.You realise how tough it can be and what a remarkable achievement it is.”  Max was initially inspired by a family friend who had been helped by the hospice. He has been through  tents so far. On Saturday the second annual Big Camp Out took place, with people across the world virtually joining Max and the good cause to raise even more vital funds. In , Max won a Spirit of Adventure Award at the Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards, in partnership with TSB, for his amazing work – and on Saturday he was reunited with some of his fellow winners. Best pals Hughie Higginson, , and Freddie Xavi,  – who won a Young Fundraiser accolade after raising more than £, for Royal Manchester Children’s Hospital Charity – joined Max.As did Harmonie-Rose Allen, the brave seven-year-old who won a Child of Courage Award after losing her limbs to meningitis. Fellow Pride of Britain winner, heroic firefighter Steve Wharton –who ed in the River Eden, to rescue a drowning boy – was there too. The winners were met by almost  other campers and Pride of Britain host Carol.They were kept entertained with live music and circus performers, and enjoyed tasty treats from a food truck during the event near Max’s home in North Devon.Some of the best moments were captured for a new podcast, being launched by the Pride of Britain team.  Hosted by Carol, Pride of Britain – Extraordinary People will feature inspirational conversation from the winners, presenters and experts as well as their emotional stories. Rachael said: “The winners all had an amazing time, they just get on so well.Going through that experience of winning together has given them a real bond and it seems like they can just pick up where they left off.There was something very special about seeing them all together, just having fun, there was no awkwardness at all.“There were people posting on Twitter about their camp-outs from all over the world.“It was amazing to see the impact he’s had – and even better, we know we’ve raised even more money.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Transportation Safety Board of CanadaCarol VordermanPride of Britain AwardsHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. royal tour of the Caribbean is over, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge will be eager to spend time with their children George, Charlotte and Louis. story: All schools ordered to open for at least . hours a week so kids dont miss outMinisters say they want to abolish discrepancies in school opening hours, with around % of schools in England currently open for fewer than  hours per weekSchools will have to open for at least . hours a week under new plans Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsAll schools must open for at least . hours a week under new Government plans. Although the vast majority of schools in England already pass this threshold, around % are open for fewer than  hours per week. Ministers say they want to abolish discrepancies in school opening hours, which are currently decided by headteachers, by . The Government said the change, which starts next September, will ensure children have access to a range of subjects and catch-up support.The new .-hour week is equivalent to an .am to .pm day from Monday to Friday. Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said a child who receives  minutes less teaching per day loses out on two weeks of lessons per year.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter He told Sky News: “The average school day is -and-a-half hours. Some schools, thousands of schools are  minutes lower than that – so we want schools to be, sort of, am to .pm. “I’d like them all to do it by the end of this year, but I know some will have logistical problems. Which is why we’ve said by next year.” The minister told the BBC the Government would set out its plans for schools in England in the coming week, with a focus on strong multi-academy trusts.He added The evidence is clear that a family of schools that is really tightly managed, really well supported - especially through Covid - has delivered better educational outcomes for children. So strong - and I underline strong - multi-academy trusts is the infrastructure we need to complete and deliver. However, unions claim the change to school hours will make little impact on students and could even have a negative effect. Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: We are unconvinced by the benefits of introducing a minimum expectation on theof the school week of . hours.Adding time on to the school week may sound straightforward, but there are many issues which need to be considered in inidual schools, and we would encourage the government not to rush any changes. Paul Whiteman, of the headteachersapos union the NAHT, said: We hope that during the year before these proposals are implemented, there can be a review of the evidence supporting this plan. Simply adding five or  minutes to a day is unlikely to bring much,any, benefit. title: toddler turned newborn baby again
story: Toddler turned into newborn baby again as illness causes her brain to swellLexie Forsyths parents have said the rare mystery condition has left their daughter like a newborn baby again unable to talk, walk, or feed herselfLexie Forsyth and her mum Emilia Blanaru Image: Michael TraillByClaire ElliotKit Roberts:,  Mar |comments The parents of a four-year-old girl have said that a mystery brain condition has left her like a newborn baby again. Lexie Forsyth from Inverness is like any other toddler and loves to play with her friends, but seven months ago she began developing a mystery illness. The condition has caused her brain to swell, which has left her unable to talk, walk, or to feed herself, the Daily Record Daily Record reports.Her parents Emilia Blanaru and Mark Forsyth, who have separated, have even described the devastating illness as rendering their daughter a new born baby again.Nonetheless, tough Lexie has fought back against the condition, following months of therapy and a staggering  days in hospital. She has astounded medics and is now able to make the -minute walk to nursery – ­something her parents feared might never happen. Doctors are unable to say whether she will make a full recovery and she still uses a wheelchair for long distances. But Emilia said: “Like a baby, she had to learn everything from the beginning again. We had to lt her up, she couldn’t walk, or sit, or feed herself.We had to put her in nappies again. “But she never gave up. We just take it little by little each day.” Lexie, who lives with her mum and brother Daniel, two, in Inverness, has been crowned Brave Child of the Year at a Highland Heroes awards ceremony. Her proud gran, Alison Canavan, nominated her after watching Lexie fight every obstacle with her infectious smile.  Emilia said: “She is a happy girl and she is always smiling.” The family’s ordeal began when Lexie fell ill last summer, and started vomiting and having seizures. Doctors initially put her ­symptoms down to a viral infection but her ­condition worsened and she fell into a coma for seven days. After two months, they confirmed Lexie had been hit by a rare ­inflammation of the brain called acute disseminated encephalomyelitis . She was able to walk unaided after four months and is excited to be back at nursery. But doctors are unable to say what the future holds. Emilia added: “We just have to wait and see. story: UK weather: Britain to go from hotter than Ibiza to colder than Iceland as snow hitsThe Met Office says cold air arrives from today and will persist throughout the week, with winters “sting in the tail” seeing snow flurries in the north from midway through the weekSnow flurries are expected in the north from midway through the week Image: Getty ImagesByAlistair Grant:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar Britain is forecast to go from being hotter than Ibiza to colder than Iceland this week with incoming snow, forecasters said.Cold air arrives from Monday and will persist throughout the week, with winteraposs “sting in the tail” seeing the Met Office forecast snow flurries in the north from midway through the week.Snow will begin in the north on Wednesday and is expected to hit Scotland and the northern parts of England. The wintry weather is expected to hit the south of the UK from Thursday. Forecasters say around four inches is expected to lie in some areas. In Wales, up to three inches will settle later in the week while Northern Ireland is not immune and will see some snow too.  Large parts of the country will be hit by rain which will turn to sleet or snow as temperatures plummet. Met Office forecaster Marco Petagna said: “A shock to the system lies ahead, with a taste of winter ing as British Summer Time starts.“Itaposs a notable change from warm to colder weather, with Tuesdayaposs cold front bringing the risk of hill snow before wintry showers follow.” The week-long cold spell will see much of the UK shivering into April. Temperatures are expected to plummet to -C in the north, while the south will also be hit by sub zero chills. Frost is expected for many regions. Highs of C over the weekend will fall to C today and plunge further to C tomorrow. By Thursday, many will be seeing highs of just  or C. Britain is going from warmer than C Ibiza to chillier than C Reykjavik, Iceland. Another Met Office forecaster said today would still bring warm, sunny spells for some. “But showers or longer spells of rain will follow across many parts from Tuesday, then turning colder with wintry showers in northern areas. “From Thursday has possible frequent wintry showers across the North, with further South having some showers and perhaps hill snow with a small chance of this reaching low levels.”The Met Office has said below average temperatures should come to an end later in April.Met Office forecast for next five days: Today: Fog and low cloud slowly clearing inland to allow some warm sunny spells in places. Some rain or showers possible across parts of northern England, southern Scotland, Northern Ireland and north Wales. Turning cloudier across southern England. Tonight: Low cloud and fog spreading back inland. Outbreaks of rain developing across parts of southern England and perhaps south Wales, heavy in places. Tuesday: Occasional rain across southern England slowly clearing. Fog and low cloud becoming confined to eastern coasts. Rain moving southwards across Scotland, followed by colder weather with wintry showers. Outlook for Wednesday to Friday: Band of rain and mainly hill snow will sink south Wednesday and Thursday, with cold air following. Rain and snow clearing late Thursday. Wintry showers mainly north and east Friday. title: uni ignored after staff member
story: Uni ignored me after staff member made sexual remarks and did Nazi-style marchPHD student Rachael Hearns, who attends Manchester politan University, feels her claims about a member of staff making sexual remarks and doing a Nazi impression were ignoredThe -year-old was working part-time at the Movement Unit when the comments were made Image: Kenny Brown | Manchester Evening NewsBySean McPolin:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar A student who claims a member of staff made sexual comments and harassed her before doing a Nazi impression, says she was ignored after reporting it to her university. Rachael Hearns, a PhD student at Manchester politan University, says she was made to feel really uncomfortable after the member of staff made comments about her body.The -year-old has alleged the person pestered her about her mask before reenacting a Nazi-style march and making remarks about her body type while she worked at the uni in October last year, she told the Manchester Evening News.After immediately reporting the incident to the universityaposs HR department she was told they would be in touch, with policy stating a manger will arrange a formal meeting without reasonable delay.  However, the student was forced to send a follow up email and wasnapost given an official meeting until more than a month later on November , where she was allegedly told there was no CCTV of the incident and it was unlikely she could proceed with a complaint. She said: He introduced himself and I assumed he was probably staff but that wasnapost confirmed until I googled him afterwards. I was getting a general sense of what he needed. During that conversation he physically stopped me and askedI would take off my mask which I didnapost want to and am not allowed to. I politely said no I would rather not. At the time it was university policy...I also donapost have a problem with it. I told him that and it went into this whole conversation about whether I had considered standing up to that or arguing that and I said no because it hadn’t really bothered me.  He said he could tell I was athletic and he could tell that I was a runner. When he first said it I thought it might have been linked to the condition he was coming to talk about. But when I said no I used to be a swimmer he said aposoh yeah I can tell.apos Itaposs not the worst but it was just uncomfortable. As the conversation came to a close he went back to the whole covid conversation and continued to press that. I made it very clear that I wasnapost interested in continuing the conversation.  Then he did this Nazi-style march. He looked down, hunched his shoulders and did a little marching movement. Rachael, who moved from the US to Manchester in  and was working at the uni part-time, claims during the meeting she was told that due to university policy all other CCTV in the area had been wiped. She added: They told me I should prepare for the likely event I wouldnapost be able to move forward with my complaint because there wasnapost sufficient evidence to identy the inidual.  The HR adviser didnapost respond to my email. Instead, in a final meeting he expressed learning about a -day CCTV policy they were unaware of. I was told the CCTV gets wiped after  days. That is very publicly available on the university website and something everyone  seemed to know about. I would expect HR to know about this. By this point it was well over the  day time limit. He expressed his sympathies and regret for not knowing about this policy but he didnapost really show any emotion. He didnapost seem bothered. He told me that the department would use my case as a learning opportunity and that an inquiry into the state of the CCTV camera in the [clinic] would take place. The -year-old was told by the universityaposs HR advisor the member of staff the complaint was levelled against wouldnapost be made aware, which she described as pretty sh***y. Nobody even asked himhe was in [the uni] that day, she said.  I donapost knowthere is an established written record of this because an accusation was never formally brought forward. If it happens again and god forbid it’s worse I have no confidence it’s going to go any other way. That was my primary concern: it’s not about getting anyone in trouble or fired. I do think Iaposve exhausted everything. My bosses are all in complete support so I feel support internally. They are angry and frustrated as well. Policies and procedures are not being followed and I’m glad the only thing that happened was an annoyance for the day. Would this have been taken more seriouslythis was a more serious offence  Why can’t I get some security  I hate the fact heaposs going to get away with it, but I also hate the fact that I donapost feel safe. A Manchester politan University spokesman said: We are sorry that Miss Hearn feels that the investigation process has not been handled correctly. We continue to speak with Miss Hearn about her concerns and we will ensure that she can feel safe and supported when at the University. title: woman widowed 25 after childhood
story: Woman widowed at  after childhood sweetheart dies weeks after dream weddingDevastated Lucy Hesford-Buckingham, , lost her beloved husband Simon, , after he suffered multiple organ failure - seven weeks after their dream weddingDevastated Lucy Hesford-Buckingham lost husband Simon, , on February  Image: Lucy Hesford-BuckinghamByFfion Lewis:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA woman has been widowed at  after her childhood sweetheart died seven weeks after their dream wedding. Devastated Lucy Hesford-Buckingham lost husband Simon, , on February . Simon had been diagnosed with autoimmune hepatitis four years ago and was admitted to intensive care just three weeks after their special day with multiple organ failure.Lucy described Simon as the most giving and caring person Iaposve ever met, WalesOnline reports. The couple met when Lucy was  and Simon . They had remained together ever since. Simonaposs condition deteriorated after a change in medication last year and he spent time in and out of hospital in the last months of his le. The pair were due to marry in December  but postponed the wedding due to Simonaposs illness. I think we always knew it would have an impact on his le, but we didnapost know it would take his le, said Lucy.  Simonaposs liver stopped working due to his condition which in turn had an impact on the rest of his organs. Lucy said that at first it appeared as though his condition was improving. She said: In the coma they brought him off everything to try and wake him up naturally. And he did start to wake up. I was sitting there and he wasnapost able to talk because he had a pipe in his mouth but he was able to shake his head and, you know, we were having quite coherent conversations. But then it all just deteriorated within the space of two days. I have to say they were amazing. All the nurses and the consultants were absolutely amazing to him I canapost fault them. They all came to the funeral as well which was lovely.Until October Simon was coping with his condition well. He was absolutely fine, Lucy said. He was perfect. We were going to the gym all the time. He was the fit one out of the two of us. But then they tried dferent medication - added some more in to seeit would give a good influence - and it all went downhill. The pair, who lived in Crynant, Dulais Valley, married on January  in Craig-y-Nos Castle in what Lucy described as the perfect day. She said that although Simon was ill on the day, it was important for him that they married. It was so nice, it was amazing, said Lucy. Simon was ill on the day and he was kind of resting and to be fair his best man was looking after him all day. But he was there for all the most important bits, he was there for the majority of the time. He was so chuffed that we did it. And I think he would have tried to get well for the first time to have it because he was just so adamant that we were going to get married.  I think part of you will always think aposthey mustaposve known they were going to pass awayapos, so part of me thinks he knew and thataposs why he wanted to get married but you never know do you. She said: When everyone puts their relationship on social media they try to portray it as perfect, but I never felt like I needed to do that because I knew what we had was perfect. So many people came up to me and said that we were more than a couple, we were perfect for each other. Simon was the most giving person you would ever meet. He was so caring. Everyone gravitated towards him because he was so calm. He was a therapist and he had this craft where he could sit there with you, rearrange your thoughts, and get you a better view on le in minutes. It was immaculate the way he would do it.  Lucy said the pair were inseparable and had only spent the evening before the wedding apart in the last six months of his le. She said: I donapost know what Iaposm doing. Itaposs been a month and still day to day I couldnapost tell you what Iaposve done. I think I am going through trauma just as much now as I was then. The way my brain is coping with it is to zone out. Obviously because I was in hospital with him the flashbacks I am having are horric. As soon as it happens I feel like I zone out for what feels like ages.  If someone had said to me when I was put on this world, aposdo you want nine years of perfection with a soul mate or  years of a mundane relationship with someone who fits the billapos I would have picked Simon every time. Right now Iaposm trying to focus on the positive part of it but I know that is going to come crashing down. There is a degree of numbness at the moment. Lucy said they used to enjoy creating YouTube videos and content together and that it is doing nothing together that she will miss the most. We just loved being together. I could go through all the memories of all the things were did together, but the things I think of is just sitting in the house watching TV. I donapost feel like heaposs gone. I know his body is not here but I still feel him around me all the time. Lucy has now started a charity in memory of Simon who had recently completed a degree that would allow him to be a counsellor. She said that Simon was passionate about providing young people who are autistic and neuroergent with accessible therapy, something he struggled to find. Simon worked alongside the Kimel foundation and had undertaken a course with them and they were later going to take him on as a counsellor. Lucy said: Simon just wanted to help people. He said aposwhen I graduate I donapost want to work for money, I feel like Iaposve taken money for something I could do for freeapos. He just wanted to help and would give anything to help someone.Lucy and Simonaposs family would gratefully receive donations in his memory to the Kimel Foundation who will be part of the charity in memory of Simon. In recent years weaposve seen dferent cake trends emerge, including wheels of cheese being stacked on top of one another and doughnut walls.For one woman, her dream cake combined cake and doughnuts and she thought sheaposd purchased just this after splashing over to have it made. However, what arrived on the day wasnapost exactly what sheaposd been hoping for. Fellow TikTok users were horried by the clip, with one person replying: Grocery store doughnuts and a one-layer cake, nailed it.Someone  said: Couldnapost even spring for Krispy Kreme smh. A third wrote: A stack of tortillas surrounded by some bagels would have made me happier. I would have been livid.After the first video went viral, garnering over . million views, Sara later posted a follow-up explaining what happened at her wedding. She told viewers: You know something has to go wrong at every wedding and my wedding had three things. One my dress got botched two weeks before my wedding, two my husbandaposs ring showed up the morning of our wedding and three my cake and this is the story of my cake. Okay so there were several red flags before this but Iaposm gonna skip to the week of the wedding when I have this feeling that something is wrong, so I text her like aposHey Iaposm so excited to have the cake at the wedding on Saturdayapos and she text back saying aposgreatapos. Sara said she then checked whether there was anything  the baker needed from her and she said there wasnapost. However, when everyone arrived for the reception, the cake still hadnapost turned up. Eventually, the woman ran in with the cake - then the three-tier stand it was meant to be on broke. Luckily, the venue had a platter and my maid of honour and sister went out and set up this little cake thing which is like all we had. It was a mess, she shared. shopping mishaps have led to plenty of teasing from loved ones.Gemmaaposs first error came about when she went to order a replacement handle for her hallway cupboard. story: My girlfriend thinks I tricked her into naming our baby after my dead catA man who welcomed his first child last month claims he was the one to suggest her name. However, unbeknown to his girlfriend, this happened to be the name of his beloved childhood cat" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Man-with-a-stubble-and-closed-eyes-kissing-a-grey-British-Short-Hair-cats-head-on-sofa.jpg" width"" "" The cat died long before the couple metImage: Getty ImagesByJulia BanimAudience Writer:,  Mar |comments After a pregnancy that took them both by surprise, a -year-old man and his girlfriend welcomed their new baby daughter to the world, naming her Clementine at the manaposs suggestion.The new father claims he has always loved the name, and, unbeknown to his girlfriend, it just so happened to be the exact same moniker he gave his pet cat when he was six years old.The cat died some years ago, long before he met his current girlfriend, and so he apparently didnapost think it would be too much of a big deal for his little girl to share a name with his old feline friend.However, the anonymous man says he was in for a stern telling-off after his mother dug out some old childhood photos to illustrate just how much he resembled baby Clementine. The girlfriend was taken by the pretty cat she spotted in a number of the photos and asked what the family had called it. But she didnapost much like the answer. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.Taking to Reddit, the conflicted cat lover wrote: She remarked what a pretty cat it was and asked what her name was. I said it was funny because her name was also Clementine.She immediately got p***ed and asked me what the f**k was wrong with me. I was surprised by this and she started going in on me about how I tricked her into naming our daughter after a dead cat. We argued until she told me to take her home. The whole ride home we didn’t speak. When we got home she went into our room with the baby and hasn’t come out since.The poster - who goes by the username u ihgfgvf - went on to clary that heaposd named his daughter Clementine because he likes the name, not because he deliberately wanted to name her after a long-dead cat.Despite this clarication, many Reddit users feel he should have really given his girlfriend a heads up about the signicance of the name before they decided on Clementine. One person wrote: A lot of people donapost like naming their kids after a dead pet and given how long you had the cat I wouldnapost buy that you simply forgot the connection. You should have told her that you had a cat with the name and then let her decide how she felt about it with all the information. Another said: Instead of being honest about the name and the feelings behind it from the beginning, you purposely hid the fact youaposd had a cat of that name. You wouldnapost have felt it necessary to hide unless you had known it would be an issue, so I would argue itaposs very manipulative to omit that information until after your daughter had already been born and named.Do you have a baby name-related story to share  We pay for stories. story: Blind mystic Baba Vanga who predicted   said Putin will be Lord of the WorldThe psychic made hundreds of predictions in her -year career, including accurately predicting the sinking of the Kursk in . Her millions of followers believe she had paranormal abilities including telepathy and could communicate with aliensBaba VangaByGraeme Murray:,  Mar |commentsA blind mystic who foresaw the Russian war in Ukraine predicted Putin would become aposLord of the Worldapos Baba Vanga apossawapos may natural disasters and warned about conflicts before they happened. She died in the mid s aged , but the Eastern European hinted at what we could expect in the future and became known as aposNostradamus of the Balkansapos.It has now been suggested she predicted Vladimir Putin and Russia will dominate the world. In a meeting with writer Valentin Sidorov, Vanga in , BirminghamLive reported she said: “All will thaw, asice, only one remain untouched - Vladimir’s glory, glory of Russia.Too much it is brought in a victim. Nobody can stop Russia. All will be removed by her from the way and not only will be kept, but also becomes the lord of the world. ” Before her death, Vanga predicted glorious future for Russia once more, the Daily Post reported.According to the clairvoyant, Russia will be the world’s only superpower. She also made a chilling prophecy about the use of nuclear weapons and World War . Blinded after being picked up by a freak tornado as a child, Baba Vanga - born Vangelia Gushterova - believed she had the ability to foresee the future. She reportedly made hundreds of predictions in her -year career. She shot to prominence after accurately predicting the sinking of the Kursk in . Her millions of followers believe she had paranormal abilities including telepathy and being able to communicate with aliens.  Her numerous predictions about world events and the state of humanity have become infamous, including claims she predicted the rise of ISIS and the fall of the Twin Towers.The Irish Mirror also told of her chilling predictions today and how some of them have come true.Specialists have since calculated that  per cent of her prophecies had happened - slightly less than the  per cent claimed by her followers. These are some of her other previous predictions: The Kursk nuclear submarine disaster In  the blind prophetess predicted that in August of , “Kursk will be covered with water and the whole world will weep over it.” Kursk was a Russian sub that Sank in the Barents Sea on August , , killing all aboard.  In  Baba Vanga said: “Horror, horror! The American brethren will fall after being attacked by the steel birds. The wolves will be howling in a bush, and innocent blood will be gushing.” On September , , planes hijacked by Islamic extremists hit the World Trade Center in New York, killing thousands of people. Europe will cease to exist According to Baba Vanga, the continent will cease to exist by , and all that would remain will be empty spaces and wasteland, nearly devoid of any form of le. Clearly not exactly right, but the UK did vote to leave the EU on June , , creating a lot of turmoil. She is reported to have said that chemical weapons would be used by extremists against Europe . Barack Obama will be the last president of the US Baba Vanga had predicted that the th US president would be an African American, but she had also added that he would be the last one. She claimed he would leave office at a time when the country would be in economic ruins, and there would be a huge ide between the northern and southern states – as was the case during the American Civil War.Baba also appeared to predict that the th president of the United States - who we now know to be Donald Trump - would be faced with a crisis which would “bring the country down”.Her chilling prediction states: “Everyone will put their hopes in him to end it, but the opposite will happen he will bring the country down and conflicts between north and south states will escalate.” Some speculate the references to “north and south” could mean North and South Korea. World War III Baba’s predictions have been revisited after another mystic, who apparently foretold Donald Trump’s presidency, claims to know the exact date World War  will start. Self-proclaimed ‘messenger of God’ Horacio Villegas believes nuclear war will break out on the th anniversary of the visitation of Our Lady of Fatima. The clairvoyant claims to have envisioned Trump would win the US election as far back as . He reportedly predicted the billionaire businessman would become the “illuminati king” who will “bring the world into WW ”. The  Boxing Day Tsunami “Cold regions will become warm ... and volcanoes will awaken. “A huge wave will cover a big coast covered with people and towns, and everything will disappear beneath the water. Everything will melt, just like ice.” China rises According to the prophetess, China will become a world power in . She’s probably out a few years here as China is already an economic and military powerhouse. We’ve also apparently got a change in the Earth’s orbit to look forward to some time before . A golden age A new energy source will be created and global hunger will start to be eradicated between  and . A manned spacecraft to Venus will be launched. From  to  the polar ice caps will melt, causing ocean levels to rise. Cloning of organs Baba Vanga’s predicted that body organs will be cloned by , and that would be the easiest method of treatment. Red and green Between  and  a classless, Communist society will thrive hand in hand with newly-restored nature. Mars attacks! A LOT happens from  to , including a Mars colony becoming a nuclear power and demanding independence from the earth, the establishment of an underwater city and the discovery of something “terrible” during the search for alien le. Some time between  and  we’ll crack time travel. Meanwhile, French guerrillas fight the Muslim authorities in France. The “secrets of the moon” will be unveiled. The end of the world By , everything on Earth will cease to exist. However, humans will be advanced enough to move to a new star system. story: Elon Musk says Tesla bot people can download personalities onto could be next yearPeople will one day be able to download their memories into the Tesla Bot, known as Optimus, which will start off le performing mundane tasks such as going shopping, billionaire genius Elon Musk saysElon Musk says people could download personalities into the Tesla Bot Image: REUTERSByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Eccentic tech genius and multi-billionaire Elon Musk says humans could take a step towards immortality thanks to a humanoid robot will one day allow people to download memories and personalities. And the the Tesla Bot - first unveiled by Musk’s company in August  - could be in production as soon as next year he claims.Optimus, described by Musk as as the “most important development”, will start out in le as a worker droid but its possibilities mean one day brain s may be able to be downloaded into it, once the technology is available.Musk, , told BusinessInsider : “Optimus is a general purpose, sort of worker-droid. The initial role must be in work that is repetitive, boring, or dangerous. Basically, work that people donapost want to do. Would you download your personality onto a robot  Have your say in the comment section “Optimus will be helpful with respect to dropping growth rates. Butthese things continue, then what happens  Humanity dies out. Is that what we want  “We could download the things that we believe make ourselves so unique. Now, of course,youaposre not in that body anymore, that is definitely going to be a dference, but as far as preserving our memories, our personality, I think we could do that. “Weaposve already amplied our human brains massively with computers. It could be an interesting ratio to roughly calculate the amount of compute that is digital, ided by the amount of compute that is biological.”  He added he was excited by the technology, but that there was some “trepidation” with the robots. Musk added: “With respect to AI and robotics, of course, I see things with some trepidation. “Because I certainly donapost want to have anything that could potentially be harmful to humanity. But humanoid robots are happening. Look at Boston Dynamics. They do better demonstrations every year. “The rate of advancement of AI is very rapid.”  Standing at about ft in tall and weighing  pounds, the Tesla Bot will be able to pick up essentials from shops as well as help fix cars with a spanner. Speaking last year at its unveiling, Musk said the robot could have a big impact across the world. The tycoon said: “Tesla is arguably the world’s biggest robotics company, our cars are basically semi-sentient robots on wheels. It kind of makes sense to put that technology on a humanoid form. We think weaposll probably have a prototype sometime early next year. Itaposs intended to be friendly, of course, navigate through a world built for humans, and eliminate boring, repetitive, dangerous tasks. title: secret new luxury home teen
story: Secret new ‘luxury home of teen Putin love child’ unmasked thanks to food delivery ordersA hacked food courier database showing deliveries to Vladimir Putins “love child” Luiza Rozova, , has allegedly revealed the teens new "palace luxury" homeA new luxury penthouse has been linked to Vladimir Putins secret daughter Image: Hod   eastwest newsByWill StewartRussia Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A new home boasting “palace luxury” linked to Vladimir Putin’s “secret daughter” and her mother - the strongman’s alleged ex-lover - has been located in St Petersburg.The pair were earlier claimed to share a £. million home in Monaco but now a spacious penthouse has evidently come to light via a hacked food courier database showing deliveries to “love child” Luiza Rozova, . It’s value before the recent slump due to the war and sanctions was around £. million. Luiza, a student, is the daughter of cleaner-turned-multimillionaire Svetlana Krivonogikh, , now part-owner of a major Russian bank, one of the countryaposs wealthiest women with an estimated £ million financial and property fortune. She has not commented on claims that her daughter was fathered by the Kremlin president, and nor has Luiza, also known as Elizaveta, although the teenager told Russian GQ that she “probably” looks “similar” to a young Putin.The suspicion that she was Putin’s secret daughter from an extra-marital affair was first aired by an independent media outlet in Russia which was later blocked by the authorities. The , square feet apartment in the sumptuous gated Fontanka  block is one of St Petersburg’s most sought after addresses in the city’s “Golden Triangle”. It is described as a “club house” with an array of “elite apartments” with construction by German company Engel  Voelkers, with “high-end” designer finishes and furnishings by Roberto Molon in an elegant and light art deco style”. Plumbing and kitchen appliances are from leading German and Italian manufacturers”.  In the prestigious development “everything is thought out to create maximum comfort, convenience and a fabulous atmosphere of beauty, comfort and coziness. “It has its own wellness centre with a swimming pool, and luxury service.” It offers “palace luxury in the spirit of modernity from Italian designers”. Reports say that Oleg Yemelyanov - linked to jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny - analysed hacked Yandex Food records which became publicly available.  These showed an unknown apartment linked to Krivonogikh at Fontanka embankment number , he said. “Wow, Putin’s [ex-]mistress Svetlana Krivonogikh has a flat with total area of nearly  square metres on the River Fontanka embankment,” said Yemelyanov. “Thanks for the tip to Luiza Vladimirovna [Rozova] who has been ordering food to that address.” The propertyaposs value has sunk to £. million in the past month. Luiza has closed her Instagram after she was hit by a wave of extreme trolling over Russia’s war in Ukraine.One comment said: “Are U sitting in the bunker   Like a rat ” Luiza - who had , subscribers - stopped publicly posting six months ago, triggering the suspicion that Putin had gagged her, but her account remained open. Now a message says in Russian: “User not found.”  One post on the -year-old’s Instagram alleged she was the “daughter of a murderer, war criminal, psychopath and drug addict”. Many posts included the Ukrainian blue-and-yellow flag and one carried the message: “The Russian nation must rise against this dictator. You donapost want to have anything to do with him.” But commenters also staunchly defended her, with one saying: “Donapost judge her...is not her fault.” Another wrote: “She cannot do anything for having a crazy father”. One more said: “Come on guys, she is just a person. She is not guilty.”  But a commenter called Martina hit back: “Yes, she is guilty of passive complicity. It is the same as most of the Germans in the Nazi period.” Another posted: “Call him -he loves you ... maybe you can convince him not to kill.” One complained: Stop writing [that] sheaposs an innocent. “She is the daughter of that devil! “She could at least show that she does not agree with what her father is doing, somehow influence him. “Putin doesnapost give a s*** for ordinary people, but maybe his daughters still mean something to him. “She stays quiet because she knowsshe says one bad word to Daddy, she will be cut off from big money, apartments and expensive things.  “Unfortunately, there are important things - and more important things. “Apparently, purses and villas are more important to her than human le.” Putin has two daughters by his ex-we Lyudmila, the former Kremlin first lady. Likewise, neither of them - Dr Maria Vorontsova, , a geneticist, and Katerina Tikhonova, , a high-kicking ‘rock’n’roll’ dancer-turned-mathematician, have commented on the war. There are reports that Putin has hidden some family members in a chalet in neutral Switzerland - while another version is that they are in a five-star hi-tech nuclear bunker in Siberia. There is speculation he has up to four children with Olympic Gold-medal winning rhythmic gymnast Alina Kabaeva, , now high-earning a media mogul in Moscow who is rarely seen in public. This would make the Kremlin strongman a father of seven. Luiza has had a higher online public profile, and was hit by a backlash over Ukraine.  One comment said: “How are you in the bunker ” A troll suspecting she may be in her mother’s Mediterranean bolthole said: “While you’re fluffing around in Monaco, people of your generation are dying in Ukraine because of your father. “Your destiny will be that of Marija Milosevic when your dad gets sent to The Hague. “SHOW YOUR FACE YOU COWARD!” She was told: “Young Russian soldiers are being sent to Ukraine without any knowledge about where they are, who they fight and what they do. “The Russian economy is collapsing, reaching absolute zero. “Soon,not already, you wonapost be able to use Netflix, Spoty, social media apps, pay with Google and Apple Pay, all popular brands and boycotting and exiting Russia.”Luiza was also told: “Many Ukrainians have forgotten about what sleep is, and even more so in bed. “After all, falling asleep, many of us run the risk of not waking up. “People spend the night in basements like rats because bombs are falling from the sky and rockets are coming. “All you need is not to be silent, not to stand aside. “ Tell people the truth about what is happening in Ukraine! “We want to live in peace and sleep peacefully in our beds, to know that in the morning our relatives and friends will be alive.” Luiza earlier showed her le at cafes, on trips to Paris, and running her own Russian fashion label. A video shows her at the Louvre museum during the pandemic. She was also seen working as an in-demand DJ. title: zelensky ready meet moscow demands
story: Zelensky ready to meet Moscow on some demandsRussia withdraws from UkraineUkrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky told a group of Russian journalists that his country would abandon its drive to join NATO on the basis that Russia would withdraw troopsUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky during a meeting in Kyiv last week Image: UKRAINIAN PRESIDENTIAL PRESS SERVICE HANDOUT EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The Ukrainian President is willing to meet Moscow on some of its demandsRussian troops withdraw from the country, he has revealed.Volodymyr Zelensky told a group of Russian independent journalists on Sunday that Kyiv was prepared to become neutral and meet Moscow on some of its demands. It would abandon its drive to join NATO and vow not to develop nuclear weapons, on the basis that Russia would withdraw troops and give Kyiv security guarantees.No peace deal would be possible without a ceasefire and withdrawal of troops, he said, though he ruled out trying to recapture all Russian-held territory by force, saying it would lead to a third world war.The aim, he said, was to reach a “compromise” over the eastern Donbas region, held by Russian-backed forces since . However, Zelenskiy said Ukraine refused to discuss certain other Russian demands, such as the demilitarisation of the country.Zelenskiy hosted a video call - which the Kremlin preemptively warned Russian media not to report - to deliver his message directly to Russian journalists on the eve of a new round of peace talks in Turkey. The president has previously spoken in Russian in speeches aimed at a Russian audience. The proposed meeting midway was on condition that the changes were put to a referendum and third parties promised to protect Ukraine, he said. “Security guarantees and neutrality, the non-nuclear status of our state — we’re ready to do that. “That’s the most important point… they started the war because of it,” Zelensky said. Russia’s media censor ordered the four reporters not to publish the interview and vowed to investigate them — even though it had already blocked a site that one of them edits and shut down a TV station formerly run by another. Zelensky said Ukraine’s main goal was to end the war as quickly as possible and make Russia’s forces withdraw to their positions before Vladimir Putin ordered the invasion on February .Ukraine was prepared to consider giving the Russian language protected minority status, he said.it received analogous guarantees from Moscow on Ukrainian. However, he claimed Putin had done “irreparable damage” to the Russian language in Ukraine through brutal assaults on mainly Russian-speaking cities such as Mariupol. “These Russian-speaking cities are the ones that have been wiped from the face of the earth. And these families,” Zelensky said.  He said  per cent of the buildings in Mariupol, which previously had a population of ,, had been destroyed, “but they were at least multistorey, so you can imagine what was there”. Smaller towns, on the other hand, had been completely destroyed. “I don’t know who  the Russian army ever treated like this,” the president said, adding that the destruction was worse than during Moscow’s two campaigns in Chechnya in the s and s. Zelenskiy later said in his nightly video address that he would insist on the territorial integrity of Ukraine in any talks. He said he was “. per cent sure” the Russian president had thought Ukraine would be waiting for the invasion with “flowers and smiles” — going so far as to send troops with parade dress for a victory celebration in Kyiv apparently planned for the third or fourth day of the war. But Zelensky said Ukraine was prepared to hold separate discussions on the Crimean peninsula, which Russia annexed in , and the eastern Donbas border region, where more than , people have died in a slow-burning separatist conflict involving Russian proxies that broke out soon afterwards. “I understand it’s not possible to make Russia completely leave the territory — that’ll lead to world war three,” Zelensky said. “That’s why I’m saying this is a compromise. Go back to where this all started and then we’ll try to solve the dficult Donbas issue.” Delegations from Ukraine and Russia are set to meet on Monday in Ankara for three days of talks aimed at ending Putin’s month-long invasion. But Zelensky played down comments by Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the Turkish president, that Ukraine and Russia were close to a deal on four points. He said peace could only be achieved through a meeting with Putin. “So we meet, we make a deal, and that’s enough — we sign a deal, stamp it, or sign it in blood. That’s enough to start the troop withdrawal process. “The troops must be withdrawn, everyone signs the guarantees, and that’s it,” Zelensky said. In exchange for giving up its desire to join NATO — an aspiration reflected in Ukraine’s constitution — Kyiv wants the new agreements to be more like NATOaposs Article  in requiring the country’s protectors to come to its aidit is attacked. Zelensky said he wanted to put the decision to a referendum, which he said would take “several months”, before embarking on constitutional changes that would require at least a year of work. “The guarantors won’t sign anythingwe have troops [on our territory]. “That’s why I think we could finish the war quickly. It’s just Putin and his entourage who are dragging it out,” Zelensky said. “Who’s going to talk about anythingtroops are still there  Who’s going to sign anything  Nothing will happen, it’s impossible.” He added that Ukraine refused to discuss two other Russian demands at the talks: “denazication” and “demilitarisation”. These were “completely incomprehensible things”, he said. Ukraine and its western backers fear Russia may be using the talks as a smokescreen while it regroups its forces for a new offensive and builds up new battle groups near the border. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live.
